text: seven surprising facts about NASA in
2012 NASA released a recording of
Earth's song which sounds like this what
you're hearing are radio waves detected
by a NASA spacecraft as it flew through
Earth's radiation belts due to
government regulations NASA cannot
provide its Apollo astronauts with life
insurance but Life magazine paid a
$100,000 policy for each Apollo
astronaut that flew in return for rights
to the personal stories
this policy lasted up through Apollo 11
Neil Armstrong submitted his astronaut
application two weeks linked some
sources suggest a friend of Neal's
slipped his application into the pile
for consideration but NASA could not
confirm this the inventor of the Super
Soaker Lonnie Johnson was a NASA
scientist who helped develop the US Air
Force's stealth bomber
NASA assembles its giant rockets in the
Vehicle Assembly Building which is so
massive that it has its own weather NASA
employees have reported that rain clouds
have formed below the ceiling on very
humid days to keep moisture under
control
the building has 10,000 tons of air
conditioning equipment including 125
ventilators on the roof the only piece
of art on the moon called the fallen
astronaut memorial sculpture was
secretly put there by Apollo 15 in 1971
the sculpture commemorates all
astronauts and cosmonauts who died to
advance space exploration though the
item was tested and cleared for flight
the upper ranks of NASA management
didn't know about the sculpture until
after it was already in space throughout
the 60s NASA astronauts were treated to
a pair of new cars each year the idea
came from Jim Rassman who owned a
Chevrolet Cadillac dealership in Florida
and had befriended a few astronauts
including Alan Shepard most of the
astronauts reportedly chose a family car
for their wives and a Corvette for
themselves
[Music]
